column2: I'm not sure, Tiger said.
column3: I'm not sure, Tiger said.

column2: I'm not even certain if it's a call or not. Come on up front and see what you think.
column3: I'm not even certain if it's a call or not. Come on up front and see what you think.

column2: CHAPTER 8
column3: CHAPTER eight

column2: PLAGUE!
column3: PLAGUE!

column2: In the control room the interstellar radio and teletype-translator were silent.
column3: In the control room the interstellar radio and teletype translator were silent.

column2: The red light on the call board was still blinking; Tiger turned it off with a snap.
column3: The red light on the call board was still blinking; Tiger turned it off with a snap.

column2: Here's the message that just came in, as near as I can make out, he said, "and if you can make sense of it, you're way ahead of me."
column3: Here's the message that just came in, as near as I can make out, he said, "and if you can make sense of it, you're way ahead of me."

column2: The message was a single word, teletyped in the center of a blue dispatch sheet:
column3: The message was a single word, teletyped in the center of a blue dispatch sheet:

column2: GREETINGS
column3: GREETINGS

column2: This is all? Jack said.
column3: This is all? Jack said.

column2: That's every bit of it.	That's every bit of it.

column2: They repeated it half a dozen times, just like that."
column3: They repeated it half a dozen times, just like that."

column2: _Who_ repeated it? Dal asked.
column3: underscore Who underscore repeated it? Dal asked.

column2: Where are the identification symbols?
column3: Where are the identification symbols?

column2: There weren't any, said Tiger.
column3: There weren't any, said Tiger.

column2: Our own computer designated 31 Brucker from the direction and intensity of the signal.	Our own computer designated thirty one Brucker from the direction and intensity of the signal.
column3: true

column2: The question is, what do we do?"
column3: The question is, what do we do?"

column2: The message stared up at them cryptically.
column3: The message stared up at them cryptically.

column2: Dal shook his head.
column3: Dal shook his head.

column2: Doesn't give us much to go on, that's certain.	Doesn't give us much to go on, that's certain.
column3: false

column2: Even the location could be wrong if the signal came in on an odd frequency or from a long distance.
column3: Even the location could be wrong if the signal came in on an odd frequency or from a long distance.

column2: Let's beam back at the same direction and intensity and see what happens."
column3: Let's beam back at the same direction and intensity and see what happens."

column2: Tiger took the earphones and speaker, and turned the signal beam to coincide with the direction of the incoming message.
column3: Tiger took the earphones and speaker, and turned the signal beam to coincide with the direction of the incoming message.

column2: We have your contact.	We have your contact.
column3: true

column2: Can you hear me?
column3: Can you hear me?

column2: Who are you and what do you want?"
column3: Who are you and what do you want?"

column2: There was a long delay and they thought the contact was lost.
column3: There was a long delay and they thought the contact was lost.

column2: Then a voice came whispering through the static.
column3: Then a voice came whispering through the static.

column2: Where is your ship now?	Where is your ship now?
column3: true

column2: Are you near to us?"
column3: Are you near to us?"

column2: We need your co-ordinates in order to tell, Tiger said.
column3: We need your co ordinates in order to tell, Tiger said.

column2: Who are you?
column3: Who are you?

column2: Again a long pause and a howl of static.
column3: Again a long pause and a howl of static.

column2: Then: "If you are far away it will be too late.
column3: Then: "If you are far away it will be too late.

column2: We have no time left, we are dying...."
column3: We have no time left, we are dying...."

column2: Abruptly the voice message broke off and co-ordinates began coming through between bursts of static.
column3: Abruptly the voice message broke off and co ordinates began coming through between bursts of static.

column2: Tiger scribbled them down, piecing them together through several repetitions.
column3: Tiger scribbled them down, piecing them together through several repetitions.

column2: Check these out fast, he told Jack.
column3: Check these out fast, he told Jack.

column2: This sounds like real trouble. He tossed Dal another pair of earphones and turned back to the speaker.
column3: This sounds like real trouble. He tossed Dal another pair of earphones and turned back to the speaker.

column2: Are you a contract planet? he signaled.
column3: Are you a contract planet? he signaled.

column2: Do we have a survey on you?
column3: Do we have a survey on you?

column2: There was a much longer pause.
column3: There was a much longer pause.

column2: Then the voice came back, "No, we have no contract.
column3: Then the voice came back, "No, we have no contract.

column2: We are all dying, but if you must have a contract to come...."
column3: We are all dying, but if you must have a contract to come...."

column2: Not at all, Tiger sent back.
column3: Not at all, Tiger sent back.

column2: We're coming.	We're coming.
column3: true

column2: Keep your frequency open. We will contact again when we are closer."
column3: Keep your frequency open. We will contact again when we are closer."

column2: He tossed down the earphones and looked excitedly at Dal.
column3: He tossed down the earphones and looked excitedly at Dal.

column2: Did you hear that?	Did you hear that?
column3: true

column2: A planet calling for help, with no Hospital Earth contract!"
column3: A planet calling for help, with no Hospital Earth contract!"

column2: They sound desperate, Dal said.
column3: They sound desperate, Dal said.

column2: We'd better go there, contract or no contract.
column3: We'd better go there, contract or no contract.

column2: Of course we'll go there, you idiot.	Of course we'll go there, you idiot.
column3: true

column2: See if Jack has those co-ordinates charted, and start digging up information on them, everything you can find.
column3: See if Jack has those co ordinates charted, and start digging up information on them, everything you can find.

column2: We need all of the dope we can get and we need it fast.
column3: We need all of the dope we can get and we need it fast.

column2: This is our golden chance to seal a contract with a new planet."
column3: This is our golden chance to seal a contract with a new planet."

column2: All three of the doctors fell to work trying to identify the mysterious caller.
column3: All three of the doctors fell to work trying to identify the mysterious caller.

column2: Dal began searching the information file for data on 31 Brucker, punching all the reference tags he could think of, as well as the galactic co-ordinates of the planet.
column3: Dal began searching the information file for data on thirty one Brucker, punching all the reference tags he could think of, as well as the galactic co ordinates of the planet.

column2: He could hardly control his fingers as the tapes with possible references began plopping down into the slots.
column3: He could hardly control his fingers as the tapes with possible references began plopping down into the slots.

column2: Tiger was right; this was almost too good to be true.
column3: Tiger was right; this was almost too good to be true.

column2: When a planet without a medical service contract called a GPP Ship for help, there was always hope that a brand new contract might be signed if the call was successful.
column3: When a planet without a medical service contract called a g p p Ship for help, there was always hope that a brand new contract might be signed if the call was successful.

column2: And no greater honor could come to a patrol craft crew than to be the originators of a new contract for Hospital Earth.
column3: And no greater honor could come to a patrol craft crew than to be the originators of a new contract for Hospital Earth.

column2: But there were problems in dealing with uncontacted planets.
column3: But there were problems in dealing with uncontacted planets.

column2: Many star systems had never been explored by ships of the Confederation.
column3: Many star systems had never been explored by ships of the Confederation.

column2: Many races, like Earthmen at the time their star-drive was discovered, had no inkling of the existence of a Galactic Confederation of worlds.
column3: Many races, like Earthmen at the time their star drive was discovered, had no inkling of the existence of a Galactic Confederation of worlds.

column2: There might be no information whatever about the special anatomical and physiological characteristics of the inhabitants of an uncontacted planet, and often a patrol crew faced insurmountable difficulties, coming in blind to solve a medical problem.
column3: There might be no information whatever about the special anatomical and physiological characteristics of the inhabitants of an uncontacted planet, and often a patrol crew faced insurmountable difficulties, coming in blind to solve a medical problem.

column2: Dal had his information gathered first--a disappointingly small amount indeed.
column3: Dal had his information gathered first-a disappointingly small amount indeed.

column2: Among the billions of notes on file in the _Lancet_'s data bank, there were only two scraps of data available on the 31 Brucker system.
column3: Among the billions of notes on file in the underscore Lancet underscore's data bank, there were only two scraps of data available on the thirty one Brucker system.

column2: Is this all you could find? Tiger said, staring at the information slips.
column3: Is this all you could find? Tiger said, staring at the information slips.

column2: There's just nothing else there, Dal said.
column3: There's just nothing else there, Dal said.

column2: This one is a description and classification of the star, and it doesn't sound like the one who wrote it had even been near it.
column3: This one is a description and classification of the star, and it doesn't sound like the one who wrote it had even been near it.

column2: He hadn't, Tiger said.
column3: He hadn't, Tiger said.

column2: This is a routine radio-telescopic survey report.	This is a routine radio telescopic survey report.
column3: true

column2: The star is a red giant.
column3: The star is a red giant.

column2: Big and cold, with three--possibly four--planets inside the outer envelope of the star itself, and only one outside it.
column3: Big and cold, with three-possibly four-planets inside the outer envelope of the star itself, and only one outside it.

column2: Nothing about satellites.
column3: Nothing about satellites.

column2: None of the planets thought to be habitable by man.
column3: None of the planets thought to be habitable by man.

column2: What's the other item?"
column3: What's the other item?"

column2: An exploratory report on the outer planet, done eight hundred years ago.	An exploratory report on the outer planet, done eight hundred years ago.
column3: true

column2: Says it's an Earth-type planet, and not much else.
column3: Says it's an Earth type planet, and not much else.

column2: Gives reference to the full report in the Confederation files.
column3: Gives reference to the full report in the Confederation files.

column2: Not a word about an intelligent race living there."
column3: Not a word about an intelligent race living there."

column2: Well, maybe Jack's got a bit more for us, Tiger said.
column3: Well, maybe Jack's got a bit more for us, Tiger said.

column2: If the place has been explored, there must be _some_ information about the inhabitants.
column3: If the place has been explored, there must be underscore some underscore information about the inhabitants.

column2: But Jack also came up with a blank.
column3: But Jack also came up with a blank.

column2: Central Records on Hospital Earth sent back a physical description of a tiny outer planet of the star, with a thin oxygen-nitrogen atmosphere, very little water, and enough methane mixed in to make the atmosphere deadly to Earthmen.
column3: Central Records on Hospital Earth sent back a physical description of a tiny outer planet of the star, with a thin oxygen nitrogen atmosphere, very little water, and enough methane mixed in to make the atmosphere deadly to Earthmen.

column2: Then there's never been a medical service contract? Tiger asked.
column3: Then there's never been a medical service contract? Tiger asked.

column2: Contract! Jack said.
column3: Contract! Jack said.

column2: It doesn't even say there are any people there. Not a word about any kind of life form.
column3: It doesn't even say there are any people there. Not a word about any kind of life form.

column2: Well, that's ridiculous, Dal said.
column3: Well, that's ridiculous, Dal said.

column2: If we're getting messages from there, somebody must be sending them.	If we're getting messages from there, somebody must be sending them.
column3: true

column2: But if a Confederation ship explored there, there's a way to find out.
column3: But if a Confederation ship explored there, there's a way to find out.

column2: How soon can we convert to star-drive?"
column3: How soon can we convert to star drive?"

column2: As soon as we can get strapped down, Tiger said.
column3: As soon as we can get strapped down, Tiger said.

column2: Then send our reconversion co-ordinates to the Confederation headquarters on Garv II and request the Confederation records on the place.
column3: Then send our reconversion co ordinates to the Confederation headquarters on Garv two and request the Confederation records on the place.

column2: Jack stared at him.
column3: Jack stared at him.

column2: You mean just ask to see Confederation records?	You mean just ask to see Confederation records?
column3: true

column2: We can't do that, they'd skin us alive.
column3: We can't do that, they'd skin us alive.

column2: Those records are closed to everyone except full members of the Confederation."
column3: Those records are closed to everyone except full members of the Confederation."

column2: Tell them it's an emergency, Dal said.
column3: Tell them it's an emergency, Dal said.

column2: If they want to be legal about it, give them my Confederation serial number.	If they want to be legal about it, give them my Confederation serial number.
column3: true

column2: Garv II is a member of the Confederation, and I'm a native-born citizen."
column3: Garv two is a member of the Confederation, and I'm a native born citizen."

column2: Tiger got the request off while Jack and Dal strapped down for the conversion to Koenig drive.
column3: Tiger got the request off while Jack and Dal strapped down for the conversion to Koenig drive.

column2: Five minutes later Tiger joined them, grinning from ear to ear.
column3: Five minutes later Tiger joined them, grinning from ear to ear.

column2: Didn't even have to pull rank, he said. "When they started to argue, I just told them it was an emergency, and if they didn't let us see any records they had, we would file their refusal against claims that might come up later.
column3: Didn't even have to pull rank, he said. "When they started to argue, I just told them it was an emergency, and if they didn't let us see any records they had, we would file their refusal against claims that might come up later.

column2: They quit arguing. We'll have the records as soon as we reconvert."
column3: They quit arguing. We'll have the records as soon as we reconvert."

column2: The star that they were seeking was a long distance from the current location of the _Lancet_.
column3: The star that they were seeking was a long distance from the current location of the underscore Lancet underscore.

column2: The ship was in Koenig drive for hours before it reconverted, and even Dal was beginning to feel the first pangs of drive-sickness before they felt the customary jolting vibration of the change to normal space, and saw bright stars again in the viewscreen.
column3: The ship was in Koenig drive for hours before it reconverted, and even Dal was beginning to feel the first pangs of drive sickness before they felt the customary jolting vibration of the change to normal space, and saw bright stars again in the viewscreen.

column2: The star called 31 Brucker was close then.
column3: The star called thirty one Brucker was close then.

column2: It was indeed a red giant; long tenuous plumes of gas spread out for hundreds of millions of miles on all sides of its glowing red core.
column3: It was indeed a red giant; long tenuous plumes of gas spread out for hundreds of millions of miles on all sides of its glowing red core.

column2: This mammoth star did not look so cold now, as they stared at it in the viewscreen, yet among the family of stars it was a cold, dying giant with only a few moments of life left on the astronomical time scale.
column3: This mammoth star did not look so cold now, as they stared at it in the viewscreen, yet among the family of stars it was a cold, dying giant with only a few moments of life left on the astronomical time scale.

column2: From the _Lancet_'s position, no planets at all were visible to the naked eye, but with the telescope Jack soon found two inside the star's envelope of gas and one tiny one outside.
column3: From the underscore Lancet underscore's position, no planets at all were visible to the naked eye, but with the telescope Jack soon found two inside the star's envelope of gas and one tiny one outside.

column2: They would have to be searched for, and the one that they were hoping to reach located before centering and landing maneuvers could be begun.
column3: They would have to be searched for, and the one that they were hoping to reach located before centering and landing maneuvers could be begun.

column2: Already the radio was chattering with two powerful signals coming in. One came from the Galactic Confederation headquarters on Garv II; the other was a good clear signal from very close range, unquestionably beamed to them from the planet in distress.
column3: Already the radio was chattering with two powerful signals coming in. One came from the Galactic Confederation headquarters on Garv two; the other was a good clear signal from very close range, unquestionably beamed to them from the planet in distress.

column2: They watched as the Confederation report came clacking off the teletype, and they stared at it unbelieving.
column3: They watched as the Confederation report came clacking off the teletype, and they stared at it unbelieving.

column2: It just doesn't make sense, Jack said.
column3: It just doesn't make sense, Jack said.

column2: There _must_ be intelligent creatures down there.	There underscore must underscore be intelligent creatures down there.
column3: false

column2: They're sending radio signals."
column3: They're sending radio signals."

column2: Then why a report like this? Tiger said.
column3: Then why a report like this? Tiger said.

column2: This was filed by a routine exploratory ship that came here eight hundred years ago.	This was filed by a routine exploratory ship that came here eight hundred years ago.
column3: true

column2: You can't tell me that any intelligent race could develop from scratch in less than eight centuries' time."
column3: You can't tell me that any intelligent race could develop from scratch in less than eight centuries' time."

column2: Dal picked up the report and read it again.
column3: Dal picked up the report and read it again.

column2: This red giant star, he read, "was studied in the usual fashion.
column3: This red giant star, he read, "was studied in the usual fashion.

column2: It was found to have seven planets, all but one lying within the tenuous outer gas envelope of the star itself.
column3: It was found to have seven planets, all but one lying within the tenuous outer gas envelope of the star itself.

column2: The seventh planet has an atmosphere of its own, and travels an orbit well outside the star surface.
column3: The seventh planet has an atmosphere of its own, and travels an orbit well outside the star surface.

column2: This planet was selected for landing and exploration."
column3: This planet was selected for landing and exploration."

column2: Following this was a long, detailed and exceedingly dull description of the step-by-step procedure followed by a Confederation exploratory ship making a first landing on a barren planet.
column3: Following this was a long, detailed and exceedingly dull description of the step by step procedure followed by a Confederation exploratory ship making a first landing on a barren planet.

column2: There was a description of the atmosphere, the soil surface, the land masses and major water bodies.
column3: There was a description of the atmosphere, the soil surface, the land masses and major water bodies.

column2: Physically, the planet was a desert, hot and dry, and barren of vegetation excepting in two or three areas of jungle along the equator. "The planet is inhabited by numerous small unintelligent animal species which seem well-adapted to the semi-arid conditions.
column3: Physically, the planet was a desert, hot and dry, and barren of vegetation excepting in two or three areas of jungle along the equator. "The planet is inhabited by numerous small unintelligent animal species which seem well adapted to the semi-arid conditions.

column2: Of higher animals and mammals only two species were discovered, and of these the most highly developed was an erect biped with an integrated central nervous system and the intelligence level of a Garvian _drachma_."
column3: Of higher animals and mammals only two species were discovered, and of these the most highly developed was an erect biped with an integrated central nervous system and the intelligence level of a Garvian underscore drachma underscore."

column2: How small is that? Jack said.
column3: How small is that? Jack said.

column2: Idiot-level, Dal said glumly.
column3: Idiot level, Dal said glumly.

column2: I.Q. of about 20 on the human scale.	i q of about twenty on the human scale.
column3: true

column2: I guess the explorers weren't much impressed; they didn't even put the planet down for a routine colonization survey."
column3: I guess the explorers weren't much impressed; they didn't even put the planet down for a routine colonization survey."

column2: Well, _something_ has happened down there since then.	Well, underscore something underscore has happened down there since then.
column3: false

column2: Idiots can't build interstellar radios." Jack turned to Tiger.
column3: Idiots can't build interstellar radios." Jack turned to Tiger.

column2: Are you getting them?
column3: Are you getting them?

column2: Tiger nodded.
column3: Tiger nodded.

column2: A voice was coming over the speaker, hesitant and apologetic, using the common tongue of the Galactic Confederation.
column3: A voice was coming over the speaker, hesitant and apologetic, using the common tongue of the Galactic Confederation.

column2: How soon can you come? the voice was asking clearly, still with the sound of great reticence.
column3: How soon can you come? the voice was asking clearly, still with the sound of great reticence.

column2: There is not much time.
column3: There is not much time.

column2: But who are you? Tiger asked.
column3: But who are you? Tiger asked.

column2: What's wrong down there?
column3: What's wrong down there?

column2: We are sick, dying, thousands of us.	We are sick, dying, thousands of us.
column3: true

column2: But if you have other work that is more pressing, we would not want to delay you--"
column3: But if you have other work that is more pressing, we would not want to delay you-"

column2: Jack shook his head, frowning.
column3: Jack shook his head, frowning.

column2: I don't get this, he said.
column3: I don't get this, he said.

column2: What are they afraid of?
column3: What are they afraid of?

column2: Tiger spoke into the microphone again.
column3: Tiger spoke into the microphone again.

column2: We will be glad to help, but we need information about you.	We will be glad to help, but we need information about you.
column3: true

column2: You have our position--can you send up a spokesman to tell us your problem?"
column3: You have our position-can you send up a spokesman to tell us your problem?"

column2: A long pause, and then the voice came back wearily.
column3: A long pause, and then the voice came back wearily.

column2: It will be done. Stand by to receive him.
column3: It will be done. Stand by to receive him.

column2: Tiger snapped off the radio receiver and looked up triumphantly at the others.
column3: Tiger snapped off the radio receiver and looked up triumphantly at the others.

column2: Now we're getting somewhere.	Now we're getting somewhere.
column3: true

column2: If the people down there can send a ship out with a spokesman to tell us about their troubles, we've got a chance to sew up a contract, and that could mean a Star for every one of us."
column3: If the people down there can send a ship out with a spokesman to tell us about their troubles, we've got a chance to sew up a contract, and that could mean a Star for every one of us."

column2: Yes, but who are they? Dal said.
column3: Yes, but who are they? Dal said.

column2: And where were they when the Confederation ship was here?
column3: And where were they when the Confederation ship was here?

column2: I don't know, Jack said, "but I'll bet you both that we have quite a time finding out."
column3: I don't know, Jack said, "but I'll bet you both that we have quite a time finding out."

column2: Why? Tiger said.
column3: Why? Tiger said.

column2: What do you mean?
column3: What do you mean?

column2: I mean we'd better be very careful here, Jack said darkly.
column3: I mean we'd better be very careful here, Jack said darkly.

column2: I don't know about you, but I think this whole business has a very strange smell.
column3: I don't know about you, but I think this whole business has a very strange smell.

column2: There was nothing strange about the Bruckian ship when it finally came into view.
column3: There was nothing strange about the Bruckian ship when it finally came into view.

column2: It was a standard design, surface-launching interplanetary craft, with separated segments on either side suggesting atomic engines. They saw the side jets flare as the ship maneuvered to come in alongside the _Lancet_.
column3: It was a standard design, surface launching interplanetary craft, with separated segments on either side suggesting atomic engines. They saw the side jets flare as the ship maneuvered to come in alongside the underscore Lancet underscore.

column2: Grapplers were thrown out to bind the emissary ship to the _Lancet_'s hull, and Jack threw the switches to open the entrance lock and decontamination chambers.
column3: Grapplers were thrown out to bind the emissary ship to the underscore Lancet underscore's hull, and Jack threw the switches to open the entrance lock and decontamination chambers.

column2: They had taken pains to describe the interior atmosphere of the patrol ship and warn the spokesman to keep himself in a sealed pressure suit.
column3: They had taken pains to describe the interior atmosphere of the patrol ship and warn the spokesman to keep himself in a sealed pressure suit.

column2: On the intercom viewscreens they saw the small suited figure cross from his ship into the _Lancet_'s lock, and watched as the sprays of formalin washed down the outside of the suit.
column3: On the intercom viewscreens they saw the small suited figure cross from his ship into the underscore Lancet underscore's lock, and watched as the sprays of formalin washed down the outside of the suit.

column2: Moments later the creature stepped out of the decontamination chamber. He was small and humanoid, with tiny fragile bones and pale, hairless skin.
column3: Moments later the creature stepped out of the decontamination chamber. He was small and humanoid, with tiny fragile bones and pale, hairless skin.

column2: He stood no more than four feet high.
column3: He stood no more than four feet high.

column2: More than anything else, he looked like a very intelligent monkey with a diminutive space suit fitting his fragile body.
column3: More than anything else, he looked like a very intelligent monkey with a diminutive space suit fitting his fragile body.

column2: When he spoke the words came through the translator in English; but Dal recognized the flowing syllables of the universal language of the Galactic Confederation.
column3: When he spoke the words came through the translator in English; but Dal recognized the flowing syllables of the universal language of the Galactic Confederation.

column2: How do you know the common tongue? he said.
column3: How do you know the common tongue? he said.

column2: There is no record of your people in our Confederation, yet you use our own universal language.
column3: There is no record of your people in our Confederation, yet you use our own universal language.

column2: The Bruckian nodded.
column3: The Bruckian nodded.

column2: We know the language well.	We know the language well.
column3: true

column2: My people dread outside contact--it is a racial characteristic--but we hear the Confederation broadcasts and have learned to understand the common tongue." The space-suited stranger looked at the doctors one by one.
column3: My people dread outside contact-it is a racial characteristic-but we hear the Confederation broadcasts and have learned to understand the common tongue." The space suited stranger looked at the doctors one by one.

column2: We also know of the good works of the ships from Hospital Earth, and now we appeal to you.
column3: We also know of the good works of the ships from Hospital Earth, and now we appeal to you.

column2: Why? Jack said.
column3: Why? Jack said.

column2: You gave us no information, nothing to go on.
column3: You gave us no information, nothing to go on.

column2: There was no time, the creature said.
column3: There was no time, the creature said.

column2: Death is stalking our land, and the people are falling at their plows.	Death is stalking our land, and the people are falling at their plows.
column3: true

column2: Thousands of us are dying, tens of thousands.
column3: Thousands of us are dying, tens of thousands.

column2: Even I am infected and soon will be dead.
column3: Even I am infected and soon will be dead.

column2: Unless you can find a way to help us quickly, it will be too late, and my people will be wiped from the face of the planet."
column3: Unless you can find a way to help us quickly, it will be too late, and my people will be wiped from the face of the planet."

column2: Jack looked grimly at Tiger and Dal.
column3: Jack looked grimly at Tiger and Dal.

column2: Well, he said, "I guess that answers our question, all right.
column3: Well, he said, "I guess that answers our question, all right.

column2: It looks as if we have a plague planet on our hands, whether we like it or not."
column3: It looks as if we have a plague planet on our hands, whether we like it or not."
